articles.headline: Palestinians Request U.N. Status; Powers Press for Talks
articles.snippet: After the Palestinian Authority asked for full membership, international powers reached a timetable they hoped would restart Israeli-Palestinian talks.
articles.abstract: After the Palestinian Authority asked for full membership, international powers reached a timetable they hoped would restart Israeli-Palestinian talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian leader, formally requested full United Nations membership for his as yet undefined country on Friday. But before the thunderous applause greeting his announcement in the General Assembly had faded, international powers laid out a new plan to resume direct Israeli-Palestinian peace talks that was designed to delay a contentious vote on the Palestinian request as long as possible.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Judges Compete for Law Clerks on a Lawless Terrain
articles.snippet: Federal judges compete aggressively each year to recruit the best law students in a process that has become a frenzied free-for-all.
articles.abstract: Federal judges compete aggressively each year to recruit the best law students in a process that has become a frenzied free-for-all.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal judges are entrusted with interpreting and applying rules fairly and consistently. Except, it seems, when it comes to hiring their own staff.

articles.headline: China, Driver of World Economy, May Be Slowing
articles.snippet: China’s economy has been a global pacesetter since the financial crisis of 2008, so signs of deceleration could add to worries about the outlook elsewhere.
articles.abstract: China’s economy has been a global pacesetter since the financial crisis of 2008, so signs of deceleration could add to worries about the outlook elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Is China’s economy in trouble, too?

articles.headline: A Tax Plan That Might Not Be So Painful
articles.snippet: Those earning in the low six figures would not pay much more in taxes when the Bush tax cuts expire and can avoid even higher taxes using flexible spending accounts.
articles.abstract: Those earning in the low six figures would not pay much more in taxes when the Bush tax cuts expire and can avoid even higher taxes using flexible spending accounts.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’re among the households with earnings of $200,000 to $350,000 or so, you can be forgiven at this point for thinking that you have a giant target on your back.

articles.headline: A Tryout Program for the Unemployed
articles.snippet: A tryout initiative with marginal success has leaders in Washington thinking it should be expanded nationally to help put people back to work.
articles.abstract: A tryout initiative with marginal success has leaders in Washington thinking it should be expanded nationally to help put people back to work.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Desperate to find a way to get the nation’s long-term unemployed back to work, President Obama and Republican leaders are supporting the expansion of a novel jobs program in Georgia to any other state that wants it.

articles.headline: At UBS, It’s the Culture That’s Rogue
articles.snippet: The latest scandal at UBS is only one of a series of missteps for the bank. Its board is deciding how to deal with them this week in Singapore.
articles.abstract: The latest scandal at UBS is only one of a series of missteps for the bank. Its board is deciding how to deal with them this week in Singapore.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Kweku Adoboli was arrested for an illicit trading scheme that cost his employer, the global bank UBS, $2.3 billion in losses, he was instantly labeled a “rogue trader,” suggesting he was an unprincipled scoundrel acting alone.

articles.headline: In Time of Scrimping, Fun Stuff Is Still Selling
articles.snippet: Consumers have been splurging on indulgences while paring many humdrum household expenses, according to industry data for the last year.
articles.abstract: Consumers have been splurging on indulgences while paring many humdrum household expenses, according to industry data for the last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: With a flat job market and an economy that will not improve, Americans are once again buckling down and cutting back.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: Putin Once More Moves to Assume Top Job in Russia
articles.snippet: The current president, Dmitri A. Medvedev, will take Vladimir V. Putin’s place as prime minister after presidential elections in March, which Mr. Putin is assured of winning.
articles.abstract: The current president, Dmitri A. Medvedev, will take Vladimir V. Putin’s place as prime minister after presidential elections in March, which Mr. Putin is assured of winning.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, who transformed post-Soviet Russia by imposing Kremlin control over most aspects of public life, moved on Saturday to return to the presidency and could remain until 2024, giving him a rule comparable in length with that of Brezhnev or Stalin.

articles.headline: Europe Seeks to Ratchet Up Effort on Debt
articles.snippet: Under global pressure, European leaders are working to intensify their response to the Continent’s debt problems.
articles.abstract: Under global pressure, European leaders are working to intensify their response to the Continent’s debt problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Under increasing pressure from global investors and world leaders, European government officials indicated Saturday that they were working to intensify their response to the continent’s growing debt problems. It was an acknowledgment, after weeks of public stonewalling, that a plan announced in July had failed to calm financial markets.

articles.headline: Mme. Lagarde Goes to Washington
articles.snippet: Christine Lagarde, the former French finance minister, has become independent since taking over as chief of the International Monetary Fund, which met Saturday in Washington, D.C.
articles.abstract: Christine Lagarde, the former French finance minister, has become independent since taking over as chief of the International Monetary Fund, which met Saturday in Washington, D.C.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARSEILLE, France

articles.headline: Speculators Get a Break in New Rule
articles.snippet: Hardships for consumers provide a reason to check in on the Dodd-Frank act, as regulators revise the rules for players in the commodities markets.
articles.abstract: Hardships for consumers provide a reason to check in on the Dodd-Frank act, as regulators revise the rules for players in the commodities markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: A LOAF of whole wheat. A gallon of gasoline. A pair of Levi’s. Americans are paying more for many basic items this year, making tough economic times even tougher.

articles.headline: Housing Slump Forces Cuts at a Company Town
articles.snippet: When times got tough at Marvin Windows and Doors, it tightened its belt but drew the line at eliminating jobs.
articles.abstract: When times got tough at Marvin Windows and Doors, it tightened its belt but drew the line at eliminating jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WARROAD, Minn.

articles.headline: Worried Greeks Fear Collapse of Middle Class Welfare State
articles.snippet: While European leaders hold talks about a Greek default, the country’s middle class is contending with raised taxes and cuts to salaries and pensions.
articles.abstract: While European leaders hold talks about a Greek default, the country’s middle class is contending with raised taxes and cuts to salaries and pensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Sitting in the modest living room of the home she shares with her parents, husband and two teenage children, Stella Firigou fretted about how the family would cope with the uncertainties of an economy crashing all around them. But she was adamant about one thing: she would not pay a new property tax that was the centerpiece of a new austerity package announced this month by the Greek government.

articles.headline: Stalking the Biggest Star in Hollywood: Its Sign
articles.snippet: More are finding their way to the Hollywood landmark. Annoyed residents respond: We want to be alone.
articles.abstract: More are finding their way to the Hollywood landmark. Annoyed residents respond: We want to be alone.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD — Tom LaBonge, a jolly and energetic Los Angeles councilman, steered his city car along the perilously narrow roads curving through the Hollywood Hills, turned a corner and hit the brakes. A couple were standing obliviously in the road, cameras aimed at the Hollywood sign looming overhead in all its cinematic glory.

articles.headline: Small Donors Are Slow to Return to the Obama Fold
articles.snippet: The frustration and disillusionment that have dragged down President Obama’s approval ratings have crept into the ranks of his vaunted small-donor army.
articles.abstract: The frustration and disillusionment that have dragged down President Obama’s approval ratings have crept into the ranks of his vaunted small-donor army.
articles.lead_paragraph: They were once among President Obama’s most loyal supporters and a potent symbol of his political brand: voters of moderate means who dug deep for the candidate and his message of hope and change, sending him $10 or $25 or $50 every few weeks or months.

articles.headline: Brutal Haqqani Crime Clan Bedevils U.S. in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: The members of the Haqqani insurgent group are the Sopranos of the Afghanistan war, and American officials are losing faith that anything can be done to stop them.
articles.abstract: The members of the Haqqani insurgent group are the Sopranos of the Afghanistan war, and American officials are losing faith that anything can be done to stop them.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was written by   Mark Mazzetti,   Scott Shane and  Alissa J. Rubin.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Scott Shane and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: Amazon Has High Hopes for Its iPad Competitor
articles.snippet: Analysts say the retailer is set to challenge Apple with a souped-up, color version of the Kindle e-reader.
articles.abstract: Analysts say the retailer is set to challenge Apple with a souped-up, color version of the Kindle e-reader.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — One after another, like moths to a flame, technology companies have been seduced into entering the market for tablets. Apple made it look so irresistible, with 29 million eager and sometimes fanatical consumers snapping up an iPad in the device’s first 15 months.

articles.headline: Saudi Monarch Grants Women Right to Vote
articles.snippet: King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia on Sunday granted women the right to vote and run for elected office, the biggest change in a decade for women in the puritanical kingdom.
articles.abstract: King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia on Sunday granted women the right to vote and run for elected office, the biggest change in a decade for women in the puritanical kingdom.
articles.lead_paragraph: King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia on Sunday granted women the right to vote and run in future municipal elections, the biggest change in a decade for women in a puritanical kingdom that practices strict separation of the sexes, including banning women from driving.

articles.headline: Magazines Begin to Sell the Fashion They Review
articles.snippet: The fashion glossies are suddenly getting into the business of retailing the clothes they write about, raising some eyebrows in the industry.
articles.abstract: The fashion glossies are suddenly getting into the business of retailing the clothes they write about, raising some eyebrows in the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Park & Bond, a new e-commerce site for designer men’s wear, Jim Moore, the creative director for GQ, can be found describing a red Calvin Klein turtleneck as “something that can take that gray flannel suit and give it a little bon vivant.” The sweater, which costs $225, is tagged as a GQ Pick, inside the GQ Store.

articles.headline: Netflix Secures Streaming Deal With DreamWorks
articles.snippet: The companies said it is the first time a major Hollywood company has picked Web streaming over pay television.
articles.abstract: The companies said it is the first time a major Hollywood company has picked Web streaming over pay television.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — DreamWorks Animation, the company behind successful movie franchises like “Madagascar” and “Shrek,” said it had completed a deal to pump its films and television specials through Netflix, replacing a less lucrative pact with HBO.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: Hearst and HGTV in a Rare Entry at the Newsstand
articles.snippet: Following a formula, Hearst is piggybacking a new publication on a successful television channel. In a nod to the weak economy, the HGTV Magazine will offer thrifty ideas.
articles.abstract: Following a formula, Hearst is piggybacking a new publication on a successful television channel. In a nod to the weak economy, the HGTV Magazine will offer thrifty ideas.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the economy sputtering, throw pillows and wicker baskets may not be at the top of many Americans’ shopping lists. Nor perhaps is a glossy magazine about where to buy them and how to make them pop against your freshly painted pale avocado walls.

articles.headline: WikiLeaks’ Founder, in a Gilded British Cage
articles.snippet: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange is more hunted than hunter these days, an itinerant with no permanent address save for a country manor provided by a former British journalist.
articles.abstract: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange is more hunted than hunter these days, an itinerant with no permanent address save for a country manor provided by a former British journalist.
articles.lead_paragraph: ELLINGHAM, England

articles.headline: A Campaign Finance Ruling Turned to Labor’s Advantage
articles.snippet: Unions are seizing on last year’s Supreme Court campaign finance ruling to change how they engage in politics and counter corporate money flowing into conservative groups.
articles.abstract: Unions are seizing on last year’s Supreme Court campaign finance ruling to change how they engage in politics and counter corporate money flowing into conservative groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Labor unions are seizing on last year’s landmark Supreme Court campaign finance ruling to change how they engage in politics, developing ambitious plans to influence nonunion households in the 2012 election and counter corporate money flowing into outside conservative groups.

articles.headline: Europe Stews on Greece, and Markets Sweat Out the Wait
articles.snippet: Once an aid plan for Greece is wrapped up, it will likely be weeks or even months before any action on a broader rescue for Europe comes to pass.
articles.abstract: Once an aid plan for Greece is wrapped up, it will likely be weeks or even months before any action on a broader rescue for Europe comes to pass.
articles.lead_paragraph: European leaders headed home from a weekend of meetings in Washington vowing bolder steps to address widening anxiety about the Continent’s debt burden. But it will most likely be weeks or even months before any new action comes to pass.

articles.headline: Sentencing Shift Gives New Leverage to Prosecutors
articles.snippet: Empowered by years of tough sentencing-law changes in state legislatures and Congress, prosecutors have more muscle to extract guilty pleas from defendants and avoid trial.
articles.abstract: Empowered by years of tough sentencing-law changes in state legislatures and Congress, prosecutors have more muscle to extract guilty pleas from defendants and avoid trial.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAINESVILLE, Fla. — After decades of new laws to toughen sentencing for criminals, prosecutors have gained greater leverage to extract guilty pleas from defendants and reduce the number of cases that go to trial, often by using the threat of more serious charges with mandatory sentences or other harsher penalties.

articles.headline: Flood Victims Getting Fed Up With Congress
articles.snippet: Flood victims in northeastern Pennsylvania, already traumatized by the loss of their homes, were further disheartened by word that the federal disaster relief fund was running short of money.
articles.abstract: Flood victims in northeastern Pennsylvania, already traumatized by the loss of their homes, were further disheartened by word that the federal disaster relief fund was running short of money.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUNKHANNOCK, Pa. — Standing in the living room of their house, now full of mud, slime and debris, Helen and Peter Kelly cannot believe that Congress is bickering over disaster aid to people like them.

articles.headline: S.&P. Target of Inquiry in Securities
articles.snippet: The federal agency is considering whether to recommend civil legal action against the company over its rating of a 2007 mortgage security.
articles.abstract: The federal agency is considering whether to recommend civil legal action against the company over its rating of a 2007 mortgage security.
articles.lead_paragraph: Standard & Poor’s, the ratings agency, is under investigation for a complex mortgage security called Delphinus that was issued in 2007 just as the housing market began to collapse, according to a financial filing by the company’s parent, McGraw-Hill.

articles.headline: Deep Recession Sharply Altered U.S. Jobless Map
articles.snippet: The South, which entered the recession with the lowest jobless rate in the nation, is now struggling with some of the highest rates, according to recent data.
articles.abstract: The South, which entered the recession with the lowest jobless rate in the nation, is now struggling with some of the highest rates, according to recent data.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the unemployment rate rose in most states last month, it underscored the extent to which the deep recession, the anemic recovery and the lingering crisis of joblessness are beginning to reshape the nation’s economic map.
